questions.text: A 7-year-old female is brought to OPD with the following deformity. What can be inferred from this? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genu Valgum

 

GENU VALGUM

 

  • It is abnormal approximation of knees with abnormally divergent ankles.
  • It can be estimated by measuring the distance between the medial malleolus, when the knees are touching with the patella facing forwards. It is usually < 8 cm.
  • Valgus alignment of lower extremities is normal in child between 2 and 8 years of age (Known as physiological valgus and is maximum between 2 and 4 years).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Genu Varum. In Genu Varum (Bow Legs), knees are abnormally divergent (bow-like) and ankles approximated. Bilateral bow legs can be estimated by measuring the distance between the medial malleoli when heels are touching. It should be < 6 cm to label as Genu Varum. Normally, it is 8 cm. The presence of genu varum after 2 years of age can be considered abnormal, as spontaneous resolution of the varus to neutral tibio-femoral alignment by 2 years of age and to adult valgus alignment after 3 years of age is well documented. The causes are similar to genu valgum except that the defective growth is on the medial side. The causes are physiological genu varum (most commonly), tibia vara (growth retardation at the medial aspect of proximal tibial epiphysis & physis). It is treated surgically by overcorrection of mechanical axis to at least 5 degrees valgus, with lateral translation of distal osteotomy fragment, by 4 years of age. High tibial osteotomy just distal to patellar tendon insertion with fibular osteotomy in proximal third diaphysis is recommended.

 

 

Option C. Wind swept deformity means one knee has a valgus deformity and the other knee has a varus deformity. It is classically used for knee deformity of rickets. It is seen in rickets, hereditary dysplasia (epiphyseal dysplasia) of bone and rheumatoid arthritis.

 

 

Option D. Genu recurvatum means hyperextension at the knee joint. Polio is the commonest cause. It is commonly seen in trauma, rheumatoid arthritis, rickets, charcots. It can also be congenital due to intrauterine positioning, which is self-resolving. It is also a common presentation in congenital dislocation of the knee. In children of less than 3 years of age, its most common cause is Blount’s disease.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given question describes the genu valgum deformity (also called as knock knees). It is the abnormal approximation of the knees with abnormally divergent ankles.

questions.text: Which of the following is the phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genomic imprinting

 

Genomic Imprinting is the phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents.

 

Important functional differences exist between the paternal allele and the maternal allele. These differences result from an epigenetic process, called imprinting. In most cases, imprinting selectively inactivates either the maternal or paternal allele. Thus, maternal imprinting refers to transcriptional silencing of the maternal allele, whereas paternal imprinting implies that the paternal allele is inactivated.

 

Genomic imprinting is a process of silencing genes through DNA methylation. The repressed allele is methylated, while the active allele is unmethylated.

 

E.g., Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome. Both of these syndromes can be caused by imprinting or other errors involving genes on the long arm of chromosome 15.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gonadal mosaicism: Gonadal mosaicism refers to the presence of more than one genetically distinct cell line within the gonads. This can lead to different genetic outcomes in offspring but does not involve the differential effect of the same gene based on parental origin. Therefore, it is not related to genomic imprinting.

 

Option C. Anticipation: Anticipation is a phenomenon where a genetic disorder appears earlier and with increased severity in successive generations. This is different from genomic imprinting, as it does not involve the differential effects of a gene based on whether it is inherited from the mother or the father.

 

Option D. Incomplete penetrance: Incomplete penetrance occurs when not all individuals carrying a disease-causing mutation exhibit the disease phenotype. This concept is unrelated to the differential effect of a gene based on its parental origin and does not describe genomic imprinting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genomic imprinting is an epigenetic process where the same gene can have different effects depending on whether it is inherited from the mother or the father, typically through mechanisms like DNA methylation.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 328

questions.text: Wasting in a child is assessed by which of the following measures of anthropometry? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Weight-for-height

 

Wasting in a child is an indicator of acute malnutrition and is assessed using the weight-for-height measure. This metric evaluates whether a child’s weight is appropriate for their height, which reflects their current nutritional status. Wasting indicates that a child has lost weight rapidly in relation to their height, usually due to insufficient nutrient intake or disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weight-for-age: This measure is used to assess whether a child is underweight, which is an acute on chronic malnutrition.

 

Option C. Height-for-age: This measure is used to assess stunting, which indicates chronic malnutrition. Stunting reflects a long-term deficiency in nutrition, resulting in reduced growth in height.

 

Option D. Height-for-weight: This option is not a standard anthropometric measure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wasting in a child is assessed using the weight-for-height measure, indicating acute malnutrition

questions.text: A microbiologist stained a tissue sample and found thin, filamentous bacteria, which resembled Nocardia sp. What other staining technique should be done to confirm the presence of Nocardia? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Modified acid-fast stain

 

The characteristic morphology of Nocardia is a branching, filamentous, gram-positive rod when observed under the microscope. Nocardia can resemble Actinomyces species on gram stain.  However, Nocardia is an obligate aerobe that stains weakly positive on acid-fast staining.

 

Nocardia is typically weakly acid-fast after traditional carbol-fuchsin staining and positive on modified acid-fast staining due to the presence of mycolic acid in the cell wall. Unlike mycobacteria (also acid-fast positive), Nocardia has a “beaded” appearance on acid-fast staining. Nocardia is catalase-positive and urease positive.

 

The Modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain (mZN stain) is a type of differential bacteriological stain used to identify acid-fast organisms, mainly Mycobacteria. Acid fast organisms are those which are capable of retaining the primary stain when treated with an acid (fast=holding capacity). Members of the Actinomycetes, genus Nocardia (N. brasiliensis and N. asteroides are opportunistic pathogens) are partially acid-fast. Oocysts of coccidian parasites, such as Cryptosporidium and Isospora, are also acid-fast. Hence they can also be detected and identified through mZN staining procedure

 

The reagents used for modified Ziehl–Neelsen staining are absolute methanol (for fixation), kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin (primary stain), acid alcohol (for decolorization), and methylene blue (counter stain). Acid-fast bacilli are bright red after staining.

 

Unlike the ZN-stain, the modified ZN stain does not require heating of the reagents. Kinyoun’s carbol fuschin has greater concentration of phenol and basic fuschin and does not require heating to stain properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Ziehl-Neelsen staining is not specific for Nocardia as it is primarily used for Mycobacteria which require heating of the stain.

 

Option B: Silver impregnation is used for fungi and certain bacteria like Legionella, but not typically for Nocardia.

 

Option C: Albert stain is used for staining metachromatic granules in Corynebacteria, not for Nocardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The modified acid-fast stain should be used to confirm the presence of Nocardia due to its weak acid-fast nature and characteristic "beaded" appearance.

choices.text: 1, 3 and 4
1, 2 and 4
2, 3 and 4

questions.text:
Which of the following method of disinfection and sterilization can also kill spores? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Glutaraldehyde
  2. Ethylene oxide
  3. Pasteurization
  4. Ortho-phthalaldehyde
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4

 

Glutaraldehyde, Ethylene oxide, and Ortho-phthalaldehyde are effective methods of disinfection and sterilization that can kill spores.

 

1. Glutaraldehyde: This chemical is a broad-spectrum microbicidal and sporicidal agent. It is known for its compatibility with a variety of medical instruments. However, it requires activation and produces irritant fumes, which are notable disadvantages. Despite these drawbacks, glutaraldehyde is commonly recommended for the disinfection of fibroscopes and respiratory equipment due to its efficacy against spores and other microorganisms.

 

2. ETO (Ethylene oxide) inactivates all microorganisms although bacterial spores (especially B. atrophaeus) are more resistant than other microorganisms. For this reason B. atrophaeus is the recommended biological indicator. ETO is used in healthcare facilities to sterilize critical items (and sometimes semicritical items) that are moisture or heat sensitive and cannot be sterilized by steam sterilization like syringes, needles, catheters, and gloves. Bacillus atrophaeus and Bacillus subtilis are used as sterilization control.

 

4. Ortho-phthalaldehyde: Similar to glutaraldehyde, ortho-phthalaldehyde is a broad-spectrum microbicidal and sporicidal agent. It does not require activation and does not produce irritating fumes, which are significant advantages. However, it is costly and can stain medical equipment. It is often used as an alternative to glutaraldehyde for disinfecting scopes.

 

Other Options

 

3. Pasteurization or pasteurization is a process of food preservation in which packaged and non-packaged foods (such as milk and fruit juices) are treated with mild heat, usually to less than 100 °C (212 °F), to eliminate pathogens and extend shelf life. It has no sporicidal activity and kills non-spore-forming bacteria like Mycobacteria, Brucella, and Salmonella. There are two methods-

 

  1. Holder method -  milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes. Coxiella burnetii is relatively heat resistant and may survive the holder method.
  2. Flash method - milk is heated at 72°C for 15-20 seconds followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A patient was treated for peptic ulcer with an H. pylori regimen. Which of the following is used to assess the success of treatment? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Urea breath test

 

The urea breath test is the preferred non-invasive method to assess the success of H. pylori eradication therapy. It works by detecting the presence of urease, an enzyme produced by H. pylori. During the test, the patient ingests a urea solution labeled with a carbon isotope. If H. pylori is present, the urease enzyme breaks down the urea, releasing labeled carbon dioxide, which is then measured in the patient's breath. This test is highly accurate, non-invasive, and convenient for follow-up, making it the best choice for confirming the eradication of H. pylori after treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoscopy: While endoscopy with a biopsy for a rapid urease test can be used to detect H. pylori, it is invasive and not ideal for follow-up assessments when less invasive options are available.

 

Option B. IgG antibody study: This test detects antibodies against H. pylori but is not useful for follow-up after treatment. Antibody levels can remain elevated for a long time even after the infection has been eradicated, leading to false-positive results.

 

Option D. Urease test of biopsy: This method, similar to endoscopy, involves an invasive procedure to obtain a gastric tissue sample for a rapid urease test. Although accurate, it is not preferred for follow-up due to its invasiveness compared to non-invasive options like the urea breath test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The urea breath test is the preferred non-invasive method for assessing the success of H. pylori eradication therapy due to its accuracy and convenience.

questions.text: What is the fluid of choice in pediatric patients?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNS

 

DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline) is the fluid of choice in pediatric patients. It contains 5% dextrose along with normal saline (0.9% sodium chloride). This combination helps to provide both hydration and glucose, which is essential for energy. Additionally, DNS can help maintain electrolyte balance, which is critical in pediatric patients who are often at risk for dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. In practice, 1 ml of potassium chloride (KCl) is often added to every 100 ml of DNS to ensure adequate potassium levels, which are vital for proper cellular function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RL (Ringer's Lactate): Ringer's Lactate is often used for fluid resuscitation in adults and in specific conditions such as acidosis. However, it does not contain dextrose, which is necessary for pediatric patients for energy and maintaining blood glucose levels.

 

Option C. NS (Normal Saline): Normal Saline (0.9% sodium chloride) is useful for hydration and electrolyte balance but lacks dextrose. Pediatric patients need a source of glucose, especially in cases of prolonged fasting or illness, making NS alone less suitable than DNS.

 

Option D. 5% dextrose: 5% dextrose provides glucose but lacks the electrolytes found in saline. This can lead to imbalances, particularly in pediatric patients, where maintaining proper electrolyte levels is crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fluid of choice in pediatric patients is DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline), which provides essential hydration, electrolytes, and glucose for energy.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image:  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Acanthosis nigricans

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is the illness depicted in the image.
  • It is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.
  • The release of epidermal growth factors in the affected area is the causal mechanism.
  • Acanthosis Nigricans may be benign or linked to a malignancy.

 

 

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

 

  • Multiple seborrhoeic keratoses
  • Drugs like nicotinic acid (Use for hyperlipidaemia treatment)
    • Other conditions associated with metabolic syndrome include polycystic ovarian syndrome, sleep apnea & non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
    • The condition is managed by dietary & lifestyle modifications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pityriasis rotunda

 

  • Description: This is a rare skin condition characterized by large, round patches of dry, scaly skin as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option B. Melasma

 

  • Description: Melasma is characterized by brown to gray-brown patches, mainly on the face (cheeks, bridge of the nose, forehead, chin, and above the upper lip). It's often called the "mask of pregnancy."

 

Option C. Dermatomyositis

 

  • Description: An inflammatory muscle disease, dermatomyositis presents with skin rash and muscle weakness. The rash is often reddish or purple, seen on the eyelids, knuckles, elbows, knees, and sometimes the chest and back.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is marked by a velvety darkening of the skin in body folds.
  • There's a notable link between obesity, acanthosis nigricans, and metabolic syndrome, with the latter condition often being a visible indicator of insulin resistance.
  • Recognizing acanthosis nigricans is vital as it can be a marker of underlying systemic issues that may require comprehensive medical evaluation.

 

References: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 147, Page nos 147.14-147.15

Williams Gynecology 3rd edition Page no 391

choices.text: Lung cancer
Bladder cancer

questions.text: A patient with occupational exposure to benzene presents with repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature. This occupational exposure will predispose him to which of the following cancers? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leukemia

 

Benzene exposure at work increases the risk of developing leukemia. The clinical history of repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening temperature rise with benzene exposure points to leukemia.

 

Hepatic CYP2E1 converts benzene to an epoxide. The epoxide and other metabolites disrupt bone marrow progenitor cell differentiation, resulting in marrow aplasia and acute myeloid leukemia.

 

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML), acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL), chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), multiple myeloma, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma have all been linked to benzene exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lung Cancer: Exposure to arsenic and its compounds, asbestos, beryllium and its compounds, chromium compounds, nickel compounds, radon, and its decay products can cause lung cancer.

 

Option C. Bladder Cancer: Exposure to aryl amines, particularly 2-naphthylamine and related compounds, cyclophosphamide, cigarette smoking, irradiation can cause bladder cancer.

 

Option D. Skin Cancer: Exposure to UV rays, arsenic, and its compounds can cause skin cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Occupational exposure to benzene predisposes individuals to leukemia, as benzene metabolites disrupt bone marrow progenitor cell differentiation, leading to marrow aplasia and various types of leukemia. The clinical presentation of repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature in a patient with benzene exposure is highly suggestive of leukemia.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient presents in ENT OPD with complaints of hearing trouble from the left side of the ear for the last 2 months. The doctor performs pure tone audiometry shown below. Interpret the audiogram? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left sided conductive deafness

 

Explanation:

 

The pure tone audiometry (PTA) shows results for the left ear, indicated by the blue color. The audiogram demonstrates a significant air-bone gap, which is characteristic of conductive hearing loss. In conductive hearing loss, the air conduction thresholds are worse (higher dB levels) than the bone conduction thresholds, but the bone conduction remains within normal limits. This wide air-bone gap confirms the diagnosis of left-sided conductive deafness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left side sensorineural deafness: Sensorineural hearing loss would present with both air and bone conduction thresholds being equally impaired, without a significant air-bone gap. This is not the case here.

 

Option C. Right sided conductive deafness: The audiogram is for the left ear (indicated by blue color), not the right ear. Hence, this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Right sided sensorineural deafness: Similarly, this option is incorrect as the audiogram provided is for the left ear, and it shows conductive, not sensorineural, hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conductive hearing loss is indicated by a significant air-bone gap on pure tone audiometry, with air conduction thresholds being worse than bone conduction thresholds, as seen in this left-sided case

questions.text: A traveler consumed oysters. He later presented with bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and vomiting. The organism seen on microscopy exhibited Kanagawa phenomenon. The likely causative organism is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vibrio parahaemolyticus

 

Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a salt-loving organism commonly associated with seafood consumption, particularly raw or undercooked oysters. It can cause gastroenteritis characterized by symptoms like watery or bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The Kanagawa phenomenon, which is the hemolysis of human red blood cells on a special medium, is specifically linked with Vibrio parahaemolyticus, further confirming its presence in this case. This bacterium's name also hints at its association with blood ("hemolyticus"), which aligns with the symptoms of bloody diarrhea seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: This organism typically causes food poisoning with symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, but it is not associated with bloody diarrhea or the Kanagawa phenomenon. It is also not specifically related to seafood.

 

Option B. Salmonella typhi: This organism causes typhoid fever, characterized by prolonged fever, abdominal pain, and constipation or diarrhea, but not typically bloody diarrhea or the Kanagawa phenomenon. It is also not linked with seafood consumption or being salt-loving.

 

Option D. Vibrio cholera: While Vibrio cholera is associated with severe watery diarrhea, it does not cause bloody diarrhea or present with the Kanagawa phenomenon. Vibrio cholera also differs from Vibrio parahaemolyticus in its clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio parahaemolyticus is the likely cause of gastroenteritis with bloody diarrhea following the consumption of oysters, and it exhibits the Kanagawa phenomenon on microscopy.

questions.text: A young child had an episode of sore throat followed hematuria after 20 days. Which of the following is the implicated organism for this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci

 

The clinical history of a sore throat followed by hematuria after approximately 20 days is indicative of post streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). The causative organism for PSGN is Streptococcus pyogenes, which is a Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus. The condition occurs as a result of an immune response to the streptococcal infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli: Typically associated with urinary tract infections (UTIs) and not with post-infectious glomerulonephritis.

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus: More commonly associated with skin infections and endocarditis, not specifically linked to PSGN.

 

Option D. Proteus mirabilis: Commonly causes UTIs and struvite stones but not post-infectious glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes) is the organism implicated in post streptococcal glomerulonephritis following a streptococcal infection.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of her breast. Histopathological examination of the mass showed cells in mucin pools and faint nuclei. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colloid carcinoma

 

The given scenario is suggestive of colloid or mucinous carcinoma of the breast.

 

This is a rare type of breast cancer that occurs more frequently in older women and grows slowly. The prognosis of colloid carcinoma is better than that of infiltrating duct carcinoma.

 

The tumor is typically a soft, gelatinous mass with well-defined borders.

 

Histologically, colloid carcinoma has a lot of extracellular epithelial mucin and mucin-filled acini. Floating in large lakes of mucin are cuboidal to tall columnar tumor cells, some of which show mucus vacuolation. Nuclei in intracellular type are pushed to the periphery, forming a signet ring appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma: Papillary carcinoma of the breast is characterized by the presence of papillary structures lined by neoplastic cells.

 

  • It does not typically present with large pools of mucin.

 

Option C. Medullary carcinoma: Medullary carcinoma is characterized by large, high-grade cells with a syncytial growth pattern, prominent lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and pushing borders.

 

  • It lacks the extensive mucin pools seen in colloid carcinoma.

 

Option D. Lobular carcinoma: Lobular carcinoma is characterized by small, uniform cells arranged in single-file lines or targetoid patterns.

 

  • It typically lacks the mucin pools characteristic of colloid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colloid carcinoma of the breast, also known as mucinous carcinoma, is identified by the presence of tumor cells floating in large extracellular mucin pools. This rare type of breast cancer has a better prognosis compared to infiltrating duct carcinoma and is characterized histologically by its mucinous components.

questions.text: The graph below shows oxygen dissociation curves. What does the curve marked as red indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myoglobin

 

The curve 'A' shows a hyperbolic curve that is characteristic of oxygen dissociation in myoglobin.

 

 

The red curve in the graph indicates the oxygen dissociation curve for myoglobin. This curve is hyperbolic, which is characteristic of myoglobin's oxygen binding properties.

 

Myoglobin: Myoglobin can bind only one oxygen molecule and does not exhibit cooperative binding like hemoglobin. This results in a hyperbolic oxygen dissociation curve, which means myoglobin has a very high affinity for oxygen and releases it only at low partial pressures of oxygen (PO2). This high affinity allows myoglobin to effectively store oxygen in muscle tissues and release it during periods of low oxygen availability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carboxyhemoglobin: The dissociation curve for carboxyhemoglobin would show a leftward shift and a reduced maximal oxygen carrying capacity due to carbon monoxide binding with high affinity to hemoglobin, but it would not have the hyperbolic shape seen with myoglobin.

 

Option C. Methemoglobin: Methemoglobin has an oxidized form of iron that cannot bind oxygen effectively. The curve would show a decreased oxygen carrying capacity but would not match the hyperbolic shape of the myoglobin curve.

 

Option D. Fetal Hemoglobin (HbF): Fetal hemoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen compared to adult hemoglobin, resulting in a leftward shift of the oxygen dissociation curve. However, it still exhibits cooperative binding, unlike myoglobin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oxygen dissociation curve for myoglobin is hyperbolic, indicating its high affinity for oxygen and its role in oxygen storage within muscle tissues. This curve differs from the sigmoidal curve of hemoglobin, which exhibits cooperative binding.

questions.text: What is the most common complication associated with the following abnormality? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Exposure keratopathy

 

  • The given image shows a coloboma of the upper eyelid. The most common complication associated with this condition is exposure keratopathy since the defect leaves the cornea exposed. If left untreated, it can lead to corneal ulceration.

 

CONGENITAL EYELID COLOBOMA

 

  • Can be unilateral or bilateral, involving one or all four lids.
  • The defect may vary from a small marginal notch to a full-thickness absence of the entire eyelid margin involving one-third to half of the eyelid.
  • The upper eyelid is commonly affected.
  • The most common site is the junction between the medial and middle third of the upper eyelid.
  • Eyelid colobomas represent an incomplete form of cryptophthalmos. Cryptophthalmos is a congenital condition in which there is a failure of differentiation of eyelid structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Restricted eye movements: This is not a primary complication of eyelid coloboma. Restricted eye movements are more associated with orbital or extraocular muscle issues.

 

Option C. Diplopia: Diplopia, or double vision, is not a common complication of eyelid coloboma. It usually arises from misalignment of the eyes or neurological conditions.

 

Option D. Amblyopia: Amblyopia, or lazy eye, can occur due to vision deprivation in severe cases of eyelid abnormalities, but it is not the most common complication of eyelid coloboma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eyelid colobomas can be an isolated finding or can be associated with various syndromes mentioned below:

questions.text: Identify the type of knot seen in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Reef knot

 

The image shows a reef knot, also called as square knot:

  • It is the most Basic Surgical Knot
  • Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”

 

Other Surgical knots

 

Granny Knot

  • Two Throws in the Same Direction
  • Not as Strong as Square Knot – Can Slip

 

 

 

 

Option C: Surgeon’s Knot

  • Initial Throw is Pulled Through Twice
  • Second Throw in Opposite Direction
  • More Stable than a Square Knot

 

 

Option A: Surgical Slip Knot (Double Half-Hitch)

  • Keeping Tension on One End the Initial Knot is Thrown Twice in the Same Direction and then Pulled Tight
    • Essentially a “Purposeful” Granny Knot
  • Following Throws in Opposite Directions to Lock
  • Allows Initial Tightening of the Knot to Ensure Tightness

 

Other Options :

 

 

 

Educational Objective: The reef knot has

 

  • Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”

questions.text: Following total thyroidectomy, a patient started having difficulty in breathing, and repeated attempts to extubate were unsuccessful. The most probable cause is: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

 

The clinical picture is suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

 

Bilateral recurrent laryngeal injury is commonly seen in total thyroidectomy.

 

  • Injury to both RLNs results in paralysis of intrinsic muscles of the larynx. The vocal cords cannot be abducted and thus come to lie in a median or paramedian position due to unopposed action of cricothyroid. This results in compromised laryngeal airway causing respiratory distress and stridor.
  • Tracheostomy is done as an emergency procedure to secure the airway.
  • Widening the respiratory airway without a permanent tracheostomy can be achieved by:
    1. Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation)
    2. Partial arytenoidectomy
    3. Reinnervation procedures - these are used to innervate paralyzed posterior cricoarytenoid muscle by implanting a nerve-muscle pedicle of sternohyoid or omohyoid muscle with its nerve supply from ansa hypoglossi.
    4.  Thyroplasty type II – lateralisation of vocal cords

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Superior laryngeal nerve injury - This would primarily affect voice pitch and not typically cause significant breathing difficulty.

 

Option B. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury - Would lead to hoarseness but not usually severe breathing issues as one vocal cord would still function.

 

Option D. Hematoma - Although it can cause acute respiratory distress if it compresses the trachea, it does not typically lead to issues with extubation unless it is very severe.

 

Educational Objective:


Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury after thyroidectomy is a serious complication that can lead to life-threatening airway obstruction. Immediate recognition and management are crucial to ensure the safety and recovery of the patient.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 339

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about the internal capsule?(INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Charcot's artery supplies the posterior limb.
  2. Retrolenticular part of the internal capsule contains optic radiation.
  3. Anterior limb of the capsule contains corticospinal tract fibers of the upper limb and face.
  4. Internal capsule has projection fibers.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 4

 

Explanation:

 

The internal capsule is primarily composed of projection fibers that connect the cortex to other parts of the brain or spinal cord. The internal capsule can be divided into three parts: anterior limb, genu, and posterior limb. Lesions in these areas can result in different neurological deficits.

 

  • The anterior limb contains fibers that connect the frontal cortex to the thalamus and basal ganglia, and lesions here can cause motor and behavioral changes. Fronto pontine fibers also pass via anterior limb.
  • The genu contains fibers that connect the frontal cortex to the contralateral motor cortex, and lesions here can cause facial weakness and hemiparesis. Fronto pontine and cortico nuclear fibers pass via genu.
  • The posterior limb contains fibers that connect the sensory and motor cortices to the brainstem and spinal cord, and lesions here can cause sensory and motor deficits Fronto pontine, cortico spinal fir trunk, upper as well as lower limbs via posterior limb..

 

The retrolenticular part of the internal capsule carries fibers primarily from the optic radiation, which is a bundle of axons that originate from the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus and terminate in the visual cortex in the occipital lobe. Lesions in this area can result in visual field deficits, such as homonymous hemianopia, superior or inferior quadrantanopia. (Parieto pontine and occipito pontine fibers also pass via retrolentiform) Charcots artery supplies the genu and posterior limb. Hence statement 1, 2 and 4 correct.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 4: Internal capsule has projection fibers - The internal capsule contains a large collection of projection fibers that include both ascending sensory and descending motor pathways. These fibers connect the cerebral cortex with the brainstem and spinal cord, conveying sensory information to the cortex and motor commands away from the cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal capsule, a key white matter structure in the brain, contains Charcot's artery-supplied posterior limb, optic radiation in the retrolenticular part, and is primarily composed of projection fibers linking the cortex with the brainstem and spinal cord. Misinformation about the anterior limb's contents highlights the complexity and specificity of its neural pathways.

questions.text: A child presented with dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cretinism

 

The child presents with symptoms that are highly characteristic of congenital hypothyroidism, also known as cretinism. These symptoms include dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia (enlarged tongue), and umbilical hernia. Congenital hypothyroidism is a condition that arises from insufficient thyroid hormone production at birth. If untreated, it can lead to mental retardation and developmental delays. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent long-term adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prader-Willi syndrome: This genetic disorder is characterized by hypotonia, feeding difficulties in infancy, followed by hyperphagia and obesity in childhood, intellectual disability, and characteristic facial features. It does not typically present with macroglossia or umbilical hernia.

 

Option C. Edward syndrome: Also known as Trisomy 18, Edward syndrome presents with severe intellectual disability, congenital heart defects, and distinct facial features. While it can present with a range of symptoms, dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia are not typical features.

 

Option D. Galactosemia: This metabolic disorder is due to an inability to metabolize galactose properly. Symptoms include jaundice, vomiting, poor weight gain, and lethargy. It does not typically present with macroglossia, dry skin, or rough hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cretinism, or congenital hypothyroidism, should be considered in infants presenting with dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent long-term developmental delays.

choices.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.text: C wave of JVP represents: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
 

Explanation

 

'C' wave in JVP represents tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Contraction of right atrium: This is incorrect for the 'C' wave. The contraction of the right atrium produces the 'A' wave in the JVP, not the 'C' wave. The 'A' wave occurs due to atrial contraction pushing blood against a closed tricuspid valve at the end of diastole.

 

Option C. Passive filling of right atrium: Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive filling of the right atrium contributes to the 'V' wave, which occurs when the right atrium fills with blood during ventricular systole and the tricuspid valve is closed.

 

Option D. Passive emptying of right atrium: Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive emptying of the right atrium is associated with the 'Y' descent, which happens when the tricuspid valve opens in early diastole and blood flows from the right atrium into the right ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Fig: Intra-arterial pressure changes during cardiac cycle. a, c, v= Positive wave x, x1, y= Negative waves

questions.text: A patient in emergency has the following lab parameters: creatinine 1.5 and BUN 45. The chest x-ray is shown below. In gram staining and culture only, rhinovirus was isolated. The patient is shifted to ICU. What is the treatment of choice in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ceftriaxone plus azithromycin

 

The patient is diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and has been shifted to the ICU. The treatment of choice for ICU-admitted patients with CAP includes a beta-lactam antibiotic like beta-lactam/beta-lactamase inhibitor (BL/BLI) combination like amoxicillin-clavulanic acid or piperacillin-tazobactam, or a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone combined with azithromycin or a respiratory fluoroquinolone such as levofloxacin or moxifloxacin should be administered.

 

Ceftriaxone are used to cover typical bacteria, while azithromycin covers atypical bacteria and provides additional anti-inflammatory properties.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Azithromycin: Insufficient as monotherapy in ICU settings.
 

Option C. Amoxicillin plus clavulanic acid: Lacks coverage for atypical pathogens alone.
 

Option D. Piperacillin Tazobactam plus ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is not a respiratory fluoroquinolone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of a beta-lactam antibiotic and azithromycin is the treatment of choice for ICU-admitted patients with community-acquired pneumonia.

choices.text: It is best tested in the fasting state on day 2 of menstrual cycle
Glycoprotein from granulosa cell of early antral follicle
Correlates with pregnancy rate of IVF cycles
It decreases sensitivity of the pre-antral follicles to FSH

questions.text: All of the following statements about anti-Mullerian hormones are true, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is best tested in the fasting state on day 2 of menstrual cycle

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein secreted by the Sertoli cells in males and the granulosa cells of early antral follicles in females. It serves as a marker of ovarian reserve and is crucial in assessing fertility potential. Here are the reasons why option A is incorrect:

 

  • AMH Testing: Unlike some other hormones, AMH does not require fasting and can be tested at any time during the menstrual cycle. The timing of testing AMH is not restricted to day 2 of the menstrual cycle as with some other reproductive hormone assessments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycoprotein from granulosa cell of early antral follicle: This is a true statement. AMH is indeed a glycoprotein produced by the granulosa cells of early antral follicles in the ovaries.

 

Option C. Correlates with pregnancy rate of IVF cycles: This is also true. AMH levels correlate with ovarian reserve and can give an indication of the likelihood of a successful IVF cycle. Higher levels generally suggest a better response to ovarian stimulation and thus potentially higher pregnancy rates.

 

Option D. It decreases sensitivity of the pre-antral follicles to FSH: This statement is correct. AMH reduces the sensitivity of pre-antral and small antral follicles to Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH), which is a mechanism to regulate follicle recruitment and maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) does not need to be tested in the fasting state or specifically on day 2 of the menstrual cycle.

 

Ref: Page no 76, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Na- Ca transporter

questions.text: A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination, signs of dehydration were present and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. SGLT1

 

Explanation

 

ORS contains Na+ and glucose which facilitates glucose absorption through SGLT 1 (Sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter - 1).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SGLT2: Incorrect. SGLT2 is another sodium-glucose linked transporter but is primarily found in the kidneys where it reabsorbs glucose from the filtrate back into the bloodstream. It is not involved in intestinal glucose absorption and thus not relevant to ORS function.

 

Option C. GLUT4: Incorrect. GLUT4 is an insulin-regulated glucose transporter found mainly in adipose tissues and muscle cells. It is not involved in the intestinal absorption of glucose and plays no role in ORS therapy.

 

Option D. Na-Ca transporter: Incorrect. The sodium-calcium exchanger (often referred to as NCX) is primarily involved in the transport of calcium and sodium ions across the cell membrane in many tissues, including cardiac muscle. It does not participate in glucose absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following scientists with their discoveries: [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

 

The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

 

  1. Walter Reed showed that yellow fever is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito.
  2. Edward Jenner - smallpox vaccination
  3. James Lind - prevention of scurvy by intake of citrus fruits

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which hormone is secreted by placenta? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) hCG

 

Explanation:

 

  • Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is the hormone secreted by the placenta. It is a glycoprotein produced by the syncytiotrophoblast cells of the placenta.
  • hCG can be detected in the maternal serum or urine as early as 8-9 days post-fertilization using radioimmunoassay. In early pregnancy, hCG concentrations in plasma double every 1.4-2 days.
  • The primary role of hCG is to maintain the corpus luteum during the beginning of pregnancy, ensuring the continued production of progesterone, which is critical for maintaining the uterine lining and supporting pregnancy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. LH: Luteinizing Hormone is produced by the anterior pituitary gland, not by the placenta. It plays a key role in regulating the menstrual cycle and ovulation.

 

Option C. FSH: Follicle-Stimulating Hormone is also produced by the anterior pituitary gland. It is involved in the development of ovarian follicles and the regulation of the menstrual cycle.

 

Option D. GnRH: Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone is produced by the hypothalamus, it stimulates the anterior pituitary gland to release FSH and LH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a hormone secreted by the placenta, crucial for maintaining early pregnancy by supporting the corpus luteum and progesterone production.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg266, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 66

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

Since the tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve, any irritation or pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal (Jacobson's) nerve.

 

 

Referred causes of otalgia. Pain is referred via CN V (teeth, oral cavity, TM joint, anterior two-thirds of tongue), C2,3 (cervical spine), CN IX (tonsil, base of tongue, elongated styloid process) and CN X (vallecula, pyriform fossa or larynx).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Facial nerve - This nerve primarily deals with facial expressions and some sensory functions of the face, not typically involved in referred pain from tonsillitis to the ear.

 

Option C. Trigeminal nerve - While it is a significant sensory nerve for the face, it is more commonly associated with referred pain from the teeth, oral cavity, TM joint, and anterior two-thirds of the tongue (via CN V).

 

Option D. Vagus nerve - Involved in sensory functions from the base of the tongue, vallecula, pyriform fossa, and larynx, not directly involved in referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Referred otalgia from tonsillitis is most commonly mediated through the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), highlighting the importance of the nerve's role in sensory transmission from the tonsils and tonsillar fossa to the ear.

 

Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 143, 144

questions.text: Warthin Finkeldey cells are seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rubeola

 

Warthin-Finkeldey cells are a type of giant multinucleated cells that are seen in cases of measles (rubeola). Measles is a highly contagious viral infection caused by the measles virus. The virus primarily affects the respiratory system and spreads through respiratory droplets or direct contact with secretions from an infected person.

 

Warthin-Finkeldey cells are thought to be formed due to the interaction of the measles virus with lymphoid tissue, leading to the proliferation of lymphoid cells and formation of giant cells. These cells are characterized by a central mass of nuclei surrounded by a clear halo.

 

 

Warthin-Finkeldey cells are not seen in rubella, rabies, or typhoid. Rubella is a viral infection that causes a mild rash and fever. Rabies is a viral infection that affects the nervous system and is usually transmitted through the bite of an infected animal. Typhoid fever is a bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi and is typically transmitted through contaminated food or water.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubella: Congenital rubella syndrome infection will have a triad of “CCD “congenital heart disease (PDA), cataract & deafness.

 

Option C. Rabies: For rabies there should be a history of hydrophobia with history of dog bite.

 

Option D. Typhoid: Typhoid fever will have rose like spots on trunk on 7th day of fever, relative bradychardia, step ladder pattern of fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warthin-Finkeldey cells are pathognomonic giant multinucleated cells associated with measles (rubeola) infection and are indicative of viral interaction with lymphoid tissue, aiding in the diagnosis of this highly contagious respiratory illness.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes scombroid fish poisoning? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

Scombroid fish poisoning is associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It follows the consumption of both scombroid (mackerel-like) fish and nonscombroid fish that has not been refrigerated properly. The musculature of these dark- or red-fleshed fish undergoes decomposition by Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Proteus species, Klebsiella species, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa with consequent decarboxylation of the amino acid L-histidine to form histamine.

 

Symptoms develop within 15-90 min of ingestion. Most cases are mild, with tingling of lips and mouth, mild abdominal discomfort, and nausea. The more severe and commonly described presentation includes flushing, conjunctival hyperemia, pruritus, urticaria, and angioedema. Without treatment, the symptoms generally resolve within 8-12 h.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Salmonella: Incorrect because Salmonella is not typically involved in the histamine production leading to scombroid fish poisoning.

 

Option B. Staphylococcus: Incorrect as Staphylococcus does not contribute to histamine production in fish, which is the primary cause of scombroid poisoning.

 

Option D. Peptostreptococcus: Incorrect because Peptostreptococcus is not associated with the decomposition of fish that leads to histamine production and subsequent scombroid fish poisoning.

 

Educational Objective

 

Scombroid fish poisoning is primarily caused by the decarboxylation of L-histidine into histamine by bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa in improperly stored fish, leading to a range of symptoms from mild gastrointestinal discomfort to severe allergic reactions.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the CT scan shown below: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Superior vena cava

 

The structure marked as 'A' in the CT thorax is the superior vena cava.

questions.text: Which type of sensation is carried by the 2nd order neuron of the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pain

 

The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve is responsible for transmitting pain and temperature sensations from the face to the brain. The second-order neurons in this nucleus relay these sensations to higher brain centers for processing. This pathway is crucial for the perception of painful stimuli and temperature changes, ensuring appropriate responses to potential dangers or injuries.

 

Note -

 

  • The trigeminal nerve has two types of nuclei: a motor nucleus and sensory nuclei.
  • The motor nucleus is singular and located in the pons.
  • The sensory nuclei are more numerous, consisting of three different nuclei distributed within the brainstem:
    • Mesencephalic Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (MNT): This nucleus is situated in the midbrain and is part of the sensory nuclei.
    • Chief Sensory Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (CNT): Located in the pons, this nucleus primarily handles the main sensory functions of the trigeminal nerve.
    • Spinal Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (also referred to as SNT): This extends down to the medulla and is involved with transmitting pain and temperature sensations from the face to the brain.
  • Four nuclei: (3 sensory +1 Motor).
  • General somatic afferent:
    1. Mesencephalic (midbrain & pons): receives proprioceptive fibers from face
    2. Principal (main) sensory (pons): receives touch fibers from face.
    3. Spinal (pons, medulla & upper 2-3 cervical segments of spinal cord): receives pain & temperature sensations from face.
  • Special visceral efferent:

4. Motor nucleus (pons): supplies:

  • Four muscles of mastication (temporalis, masseter, medial & lateral pterygoid).
  • Other four muscles (Anterior belly of diagstic, mylohyoid, tensor tympani & tensor palati).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proprioception: Proprioception is managed by the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus. This nucleus is responsible for sensing the position and movement of the jaw muscles, contributing to reflexes such as the jaw jerk.

 

Option B. Touch: The chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve handles the sensation of touch. This nucleus receives tactile information from the face and transmits it to the brain.

 

Option D. Vibration: Vibration sense is also managed by the chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. This nucleus is involved in processing detailed touch and vibratory sensations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve carries pain and temperature sensations, distinguishing it from the other nuclei responsible for proprioception, touch, and vibration.

questions.text: A patient presents with neck swelling, compressing the trachea and esophagus. Histopathological assessment shows cell nests and pink extracellular amyloid stroma. What is the cell of origin of this tumor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parafollicular C cells

 

The presence of amyloid stroma in the context of a thyroid tumor is indicative of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Medullary thyroid carcinoma arises from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland. These cells are responsible for secreting calcitonin, a hormone involved in calcium homeostasis. The amyloid stroma seen in MTC is due to the deposition of calcitonin-derived polypeptides.

 

Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC): This is a unique type of thyroid cancer that originates from parafollicular C cells. The hallmark of MTC is the presence of amyloid stroma, which results from calcitonin secretion by these cells.

 

Note -

 

  • The tumor marker for Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC) and Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma (FTC) is thyroglobulin.
  • The tumor marker for Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) is calcitonin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Askanazy cells: These cells, also known as Hurthle cells, are large eosinophilic cells found in the thyroid gland but are typically associated with Hurthle cell carcinoma, not medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option C. Hurthle cells: These cells are a variant of follicular cells and are characteristic of Hurthle cell carcinoma. They do not produce amyloid stroma.

 

Option D. Follicular cells: These cells give rise to other types of thyroid cancers, such as papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) and follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC). These tumors do not typically feature amyloid stroma and are more commonly associated with thyroglobulin as a tumor marker, not calcitonin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is characterized by amyloid stroma and originates from parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland.

choices.text: Prevents atelectasis of lung and alveolar collapse
Reduces CO2 in alveoli
Decreases inspiratory pressure
Increases venous return and thus maintains cardiac output

questions.text: In a patient on mechanical ventilation and placed in prone position which of the following about PEEP is true? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prevents atelectasis of lung and alveolar collapse

 

Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) is a crucial component of mechanical ventilation, particularly in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or other conditions leading to alveolar collapse. PEEP works by maintaining a certain amount of pressure in the lungs at the end of expiration, which helps to keep the alveoli open, preventing their collapse (atelectasis). This is especially important in the prone position, where the distribution of ventilation can be more uniform, improving oxygenation and lung mechanics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduces CO2 in alveoli: This option is incorrect because the primary role of PEEP is not to reduce CO2 levels in the alveoli but to prevent alveolar collapse and improve oxygenation. CO2 removal is more dependent on ventilation rate and tidal volume.

 

Option C. Decreases inspiratory pressure: This option is incorrect because PEEP typically increases the baseline pressure in the lungs, which can actually increase the overall mean airway pressure during inspiration. It does not decrease inspiratory pressure.

 

Option D. Increases venous return and thus maintains cardiac output: This option is incorrect because, in fact, PEEP can decrease venous return due to the increased intrathoracic pressure it creates. This decrease in venous return can lead to a reduction in cardiac output, especially in patients with pre-existing cardiovascular compromise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PEEP is primarily used to prevent alveolar collapse (atelectasis) and maintain lung recruitment, especially in conditions like ARDS or when the patient is positioned prone during mechanical ventilation.

questions.text: Methotrexate reduces the synthesis of: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TMP

 

Methotrexate inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, which is crucial for the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from dihydrofolate. Tetrahydrofolate is required for the synthesis of thymidylate (TMP), as it acts as a one-carbon donor in the conversion of deoxyuridine monophosphate (dUMP) to deoxythymidine monophosphate (dTMP) by thymidylate synthase. By inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, methotrexate indirectly reduces the availability of tetrahydrofolate, thereby decreasing the synthesis of TMP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GMP: Guanosine monophosphate (GMP) synthesis is not directly affected by methotrexate. GMP is a purine nucleotide, and its synthesis primarily involves different enzymes that are not dependent on thymidylate synthase or dihydrofolate reductase.

 

Option C. CMP: Cytidine monophosphate (CMP) synthesis involves pathways that are independent of tetrahydrofolate and thymidylate synthase, so methotrexate does not significantly impact its production.

 

Option D. AMP: Adenosine monophosphate (AMP) is another purine nucleotide whose synthesis does not involve dihydrofolate reductase or thymidylate synthase, so methotrexate does not directly affect its synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, leading to reduced synthesis of TMP by limiting tetrahydrofolate availability.

questions.text: A 4-week-old child with a history of vomiting undergoes imaging as shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Congenital Pyloric Stenosis


The correct diagnosis is Congenital Pyloric Stenosis. This condition typically presents in infants between 3-6 weeks of age with symptoms of projectile, non-bilious vomiting, and a palpable olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen. The ultrasound image shows a thickened pylorus muscle and a distended stomach, which are characteristic findings of pyloric stenosis. The hypertrophied pyloric muscle obstructs gastric emptying, leading to the clinical symptoms observed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duodenal Atresia: Duodenal atresia is a congenital condition usually presenting at birth with bilious vomiting due to a blockage in the duodenum. It is often associated with a “double bubble” sign on imaging. The condition does not fit the presentation of a 4-week-old with the typical findings seen in the ultrasound provided.

 

Option C. Annular Pancreas: Annular pancreas is a congenital anomaly where the pancreas encircles the duodenum, potentially causing obstruction. It usually presents with symptoms soon after birth, similar to duodenal atresia, including bilious vomiting. This condition would not show the thickened pylorus seen in the ultrasound provided.

 

Option D. Volvulus: Volvulus, often associated with malrotation of the midgut, can present at any age, including the newborn period or later in life. It typically presents with bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and sometimes acute abdominal pain. The ultrasound findings here do not indicate the twisted bowel loops characteristic of volvulus but rather show a thickened pyloric muscle.

 

Educational Objective:


Congenital Pyloric Stenosis is characterized by the hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, leading to projectile, non-bilious vomiting in infants aged 3-6 weeks. Ultrasound is diagnostic, showing a thickened pyloric muscle and a distended stomach, distinguishing it from other causes of vomiting in infancy.

questions.text: Which gene is commonly associated with the development of a round blue cell tumor in a child who underwent surgery for ocular malignancy? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rb gene

 

Gene responsible for the tumor development is Rb gene

 

Rb gene located on chromosome 13q14 its mutation seen in retinoblastoma it is the most common intraocular malignancy in children.

 

Imp. Clinical features of retinoblastoma:

  • Leukocoria (White pupillary reflex)
  • Strabismus
  • Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. P53 Gene: The P53 gene is a tumor suppressor gene involved in many cancers but not specifically in retinoblastoma.

 

Option C. P57 Gene: P57 is involved in the regulation of cell cycle and growth but is not associated with retinoblastoma.

 

Option D. RET: The RET gene is involved in multiple endocrine neoplasia and medullary thyroid cancer, not retinoblastoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rb gene mutation is responsible for retinoblastoma, the most common intraocular malignancy in children.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a long history of chronic smoking presents to the clinic with respiratory symptoms. Upon examination, it is noted that the lining epithelium of his respiratory tract has undergone a notable change. The transition from columnar epithelium to stratified squamous epithelium is evident, as depicted in the provided image. To identify this specific change, what is the term used to describe this alteration in the lining epithelium? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metaplasia

 

The change described in the question is called metaplasia. It is defined as a reversible change in which one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type.

 

 

 

Metaplasia of normal columnar (left) to squamous epithelium (right) in a bronchus

 

  • Another example of metaplasia: BARRETTs esophagus

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysplasia: Dysplasia refers to abnormal development or growth of cells, tissues, or organs. It is characterized by changes in cell size, shape, and organization. Dysplasia can be a precursor to cancer but does not describe the replacement of one cell type by another.

 

Option B. Hypertrophy: Hypertrophy is the increase in the size of cells, leading to an increase in the size of the tissue or organ. It does not involve a change in the cell type.

 

Option C. Atrophy: Atrophy refers to the reduction in the size of cells, tissues, or organs, often due to decreased use, insufficient nutrition, or aging. It does not involve a change in the cell type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metaplasia is the term used to describe the reversible change where one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type, often as an adaptive response to chronic irritation or inflammation, such as the transition from columnar to squamous epithelium in the respiratory tract of chronic smokers.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man from Mumbai presents to a clinic with fatigue and weakness. His family has a history of chronic diseases, but he himself has been asymptomatic until recently. The physician explains the different stages of disease progression and the interventions required. Which of the following best matches the stages with their relevant descriptions? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1-d, 2-b, 3-a, 4-c

 

  • Natural history of disease refers to the progression of a disease in an individual over time, in the absence of treatment. It has two phases, a period of pre-pathogenesis and a period of pathogenesis.

 

 

  • The period of pre-pathogenesis is before the onset of disease in humans.
  • An interaction between the agent, host and the environment occurs in this phase before the pathogenesis.
  • It starts with appropriate exposure to or accumulation of factors sufficient for the disease process to begin in a susceptible host.
  • The exposure is a microorganism in an infectious disease. For lung cancer, it is any factor that initiates the process, such as asbestos fibres or components in tobacco smoke.
  • Primary prevention (health promotion and specific protection) is applicable in this period.
  • The period of pathogenesis starts after the disease process has been triggered and pathological changes occur without the individual being aware of it.
  • It begins with the entry of the organism till recovery, death, or disability.
  • The subclinical or asymptomatic period between exposure and onset of symptoms is called the incubation period for infectious diseases, and the latency period for chronic diseases.
  • The onset of clinical symptoms is the beginning of the clinical stage of the disease.
  • Secondary (halting of the disease process) and tertiary prevention (measures to limit disability) are applicable in this period.
  • Rehabilitation has been defined as the use of medical, social, educational, and vocational measures for training the individual to the highest possible level of functional ability.
  • It is a part of tertiary prevention like providing callipers for walking patients and arranging schooling after being affected by polio.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a breast condition as demonstrated in the image below. This condition is due to invasion of? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dermal lymphatics

 

The image demonstrates a peau d'orange (orange peel) appearance of the breast, which occurs due to the blockade of superficial dermal lymphatics by tumor invasion. This blockage causes edema in the breast, making the sweat glands and hair follicles more prominent and resulting in the typical orange peel appearance. Additionally, infiltration of the ligaments of Cooper can result in dimpling of the skin.

 

  • Dermal lymphatics: Blockade by tumor invasion leads to edema, causing the peau d'orange appearance.
  • Deep lymphatics: Involvement would likely lead to different clinical manifestations, not specifically the peau d'orange appearance.
  • Superficial veins: Blockage would more likely result in visible vein distention or other vascular issues rather than the peau d'orange appearance.
  • Deep veins: Similar to deep lymphatics, involvement would not specifically cause the characteristic peau d'orange appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Deep lymphatics: Incorrect. While the deep lymphatics can be involved in breast cancer spread, they are not specifically responsible for the peau d'orange appearance.

 

Option C. Superficial veins: Incorrect. Blockage or involvement of superficial veins would result in different symptoms, such as vein distention, and is not typically associated with the peau d'orange appearance.

 

Option D. Deep veins: Incorrect. Similar to deep lymphatics, involvement of deep veins would not specifically cause the characteristic peau d'orange appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The peau d'orange appearance of the breast is due to blockage of the superficial dermal lymphatics by tumor invasion, leading to edema and the characteristic skin changes.

questions.text: Enzyme defect in McArdle’s Disease?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myophosphorylase

 

This is the correct answer. McArdle's Disease results from a deficiency of myophosphorylase, which is an enzyme responsible for breaking down glycogen into glucose within muscle cells. The lack of myophosphorylase impairs the ability of muscle cells to release glucose from glycogen during physical activity, leading to muscle fatigue, pain, and other symptoms typically observed in McArdle's Disease patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose-6-phosphatase: This enzyme is involved in glucose metabolism in the liver, not in muscle cells. Deficiencies in glucose-6-phosphatase lead to other types of Glycogen Storage Diseases, such as Von Gierke's Disease (GSD Ia).

 

Option C. Glycogen synthase : While this enzyme plays a role in glycogen metabolism, it is not the enzyme affected in McArdle's Disease. Instead, it is myophosphorylase that is deficient in this condition.

 

Option D. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is involved in the initial steps of glucose metabolism but is not directly related to glycogen breakdown or McArdle's Disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McArdle's disease is Type V glycogen storage disease that occurs due to deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase (Myophosphorylase) enzyme. In this disease, muscle glycogen cannot be used during exercise, so, on strenuous exercise there are muscles cramps. Also, normal or relatively low levels of lactate will be formed from muscle glycogen after exercise.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 167

choices.text: Opening of calcium channels

questions.text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation, the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opening of calcium channels

 

Explanation

 

Renal autoregulation is important to maintain the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Blood flow to kidneys remains normal even when the mean arterial blood pressure varies widely between 60 mm Hg and 180 mm Hg. This helps to maintain normal GFR.

 

Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:

 

  1. Myogenic response
  2. Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF)

 

1. MYOGENIC RESPONSE

 

Whenever, the blood flow to kidneys increases,  →  stretches the elastic wall of the afferent arteriole →  Stretching of the vessel wall increases the flow of calcium ions from extracellular fluid into the cells →  The influx of calcium ions leads to the contraction of smooth muscles in afferent arteriole, which causes constriction of afferent arteriole →  So, the blood flow is decreased.

 

 

2. TGF

 

The macula densa, a plaque of specialized tubular epithelial cells located in the distal tubule, monitors the NaCl concentration of the tubular fluid and sends an as of yet unidentified signal to control glomerular hemodynamics. In this mechanism, called tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF), an increase in NaCl concentration at the macula densa constricts the glomerular afferent arteriole and thus decreases the single-nephron GFR. Along with the myogenic response, TGF significantly contributes to renal autoregulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NO: Incorrect, as nitric oxide generally causes vasodilation, not the contraction associated with the myogenic response.

 

Option B. Noradrenaline: Incorrect, although noradrenaline can affect blood vessel tone, it is not directly involved in the myogenic response mechanism of renal autoregulation.

 

Option D. Adenosine: Incorrect, adenosine is more involved in tubuloglomerular feedback rather than the myogenic mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In renal autoregulation, the myogenic hypothesis states that the afferent arterioles contract in response to increased blood pressure, which stretches the arteriole walls. This contraction is mediated by the opening of calcium channels, leading to an influx of calcium ions and subsequent constriction of the arteriole, thereby helping to stabilize GFR across varying blood pressures.
